articles.headline: Report Warned Wal-Mart of Risks Before Bias Suit
articles.snippet: A report prepared for the company in 1995 found widespread gender disparities in pay and promotion at Wal-Mart and Sam’s Club stores.
articles.abstract: A report prepared for the company in 1995 found widespread gender disparities in pay and promotion at Wal-Mart and Sam’s Club stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than six years before the biggest sex discrimination lawsuit in history was filed against Wal-Mart Stores, the company hired a prominent law firm to examine its vulnerability to just such a suit.

articles.headline: Daniel K. Tarullo, a Star Regulator at the Fed
articles.snippet: After holding stress tests of 19 firms and tightening the oversight by Fed regulators, he has become an influential voice in rewriting the rules for Wall Street.
articles.abstract: After holding stress tests of 19 firms and tightening the oversight by Fed regulators, he has become an influential voice in rewriting the rules for Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As finishing touches are put on the most comprehensive rewriting of financial rules since the Depression, a 57-year-old former law professor is emerging as one of the most influential financial regulators in the United States.

articles.headline: Creative Artists Weighs Equity Group Alliance
articles.snippet: The Creative Artists Agency has been in discussions with private equity firms about a potential joint venture to expand its sports business, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.abstract: The Creative Artists Agency has been in discussions with private equity firms about a potential joint venture to expand its sports business, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The Creative Artists Agency, the powerhouse for entertainment and sports talent, has been in discussions with private equity firms like Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and TPG about a potential alliance or joint venture to expand its sports business, according to people briefed on the talks.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: A Jobless Rate Still Unaffected by New Hiring
articles.snippet: Many unemployed people are beginning to look for work again, encouraged by reports of a strengthening economy.
articles.abstract: Many unemployed people are beginning to look for work again, encouraged by reports of a strengthening economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCHAUMBURG, Ill.  After hemorrhaging jobs for months, the economy is finally starting to add them. Yet the unemployment rate is not really budging because of people like Regina Myles.

articles.headline: Russia Turns a Deaf Ear as Killing Cries for Justice
articles.snippet: The killing of an opposition figure stirred outrage in the north Caucasus, but only one man was sentenced, to house arrest.
articles.abstract: The killing of an opposition figure stirred outrage in the north Caucasus, but only one man was sentenced, to house arrest.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAGAS, Russia  Only one spectator showed up for the final hearing in the killing of Magomed Yevloyev. He was a broad-beamed, ruddy-faced man in a carefully pressed black suit, and once in the courtroom he removed his tall fur hat, set it on the bench beside him and waited for a chance to speak.

articles.headline: Mix of Politics and Banking in Spain’s Woes
articles.snippet: Spain’s government has taken its time in cleaning up cajas, which were once controlled by Catholic charities and gradually taken over by regional politicians.
articles.abstract: Spain’s government has taken its time in cleaning up cajas, which were once controlled by Catholic charities and gradually taken over by regional politicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: CÓRDOBA, Spain  “In the name of Jesus Christ, amen.”

articles.headline: Another Torrent BP Works to Stem: Its C.E.O.
articles.snippet: BP, already bedeviled by the oil spill, now finds itself with one more problem: Tony Hayward, its gaffe-prone chief executive.
articles.abstract: BP, already bedeviled by the oil spill, now finds itself with one more problem: Tony Hayward, its gaffe-prone chief executive.
articles.lead_paragraph: BP, already bedeviled by an out-of-control well spewing millions of gallons of oil into the Gulf of Mexico, now finds itself with one more problem: Tony Hayward, its gaffe-prone chief executive.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: McDonald’s to Recall Glasses, Citing Cadmium
articles.snippet: McDonald’s said it was recalling promotional drink glasses in light of the “evolving assessment of standards for consumer products.”
articles.abstract: McDonald’s said it was recalling promotional drink glasses in light of the “evolving assessment of standards for consumer products.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Could cadmium be the new lead? Some parents and consumer advocates think so.

articles.headline: U.S. Indexes Fall Sharply on Jobs Data
articles.snippet: The markets skidded, as the latest unemployment figures raised concerns about the strength of the recovery.
articles.abstract: The markets skidded, as the latest unemployment figures raised concerns about the strength of the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks tumbled Friday in one of their sharpest declines this year, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average firmly below 10,000, as a disappointing jobs report cast a pall over the nation’s economic recovery.

articles.headline: Job Data Casts Pall Over Economic Recovery
articles.snippet: Employers added 431,000 nonfarm jobs, the biggest monthly increase in a decade, but most of the reported growth was in government jobs.
articles.abstract: Employers added 431,000 nonfarm jobs, the biggest monthly increase in a decade, but most of the reported growth was in government jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: A shadow fell across America’s economic recovery on Friday, as the Labor Department’s monthly report showed that job growth was weak in the private sector, provoking a precipitous sell-off in the stock market.
